claim: A 41-year-old woman presents with pain in her abdomen for the last couple of hours. She says pain is intermittent and localized to the right hypochondriac region. She admits to eating fatty foods this morning before the pain started. She also complains of nausea but has not vomited yet. She describes episodes with similar symptoms in the past after a fatty meal but were less severe. Past medical history is irrelevant. The vital signs include: heart rate 85/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.6°F), and blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination is within normal limits. An abdominal ultrasound is pending. Which of the following hormones most likely is the cause of the postprandial aggravation of this patient's symptoms? : Gastrin

supporting.text: Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion, which can exacerbate symptoms in conditions like peptic ulcers or gastritis, but these are less likely given the localization to the right hypochondriac region and association with fatty foods.

Cholecystokinin (CCK) is more likely the cause, as it is released in response to fatty foods and can trigger gallbladder contraction, leading to pain in the right hypochondriac region, consistent with biliary colic or cholelithiasis.
The patient's symptoms are classic for biliary colic, which is caused by gallbladder contraction against an obstructed cystic duct, not gastrin-mediated acid secretion.

Functional dyspepsia is a diagnosis of exclusion and cannot be confirmed without ruling out biliary pathology, which remains the more likely etiology given the clinical presentation.
